title: 108_hr2124
content: The "Foster Care Reform Commission Act" establishes a commission to study the foster care crisis in the United States and identify best practices for safe and reliable foster care. The "Foster Care Reform Commission Act" mandates the appointment of 4 Congressional members and 11 additional members by the Commission chairman, with a focus on expertise in child care. The "Foster Care Reform Commission Act" requires the appointment of 11 experts in child care and foster care issues from the private sector, public sector, and academia. Commission members must have diverse political affiliations, serve for the life of the Commission, and not receive compensation. Travel expenses are provided for each member. The Commission members receive travel expenses, including per diem, as outlined in applicable provisions. A quorum consists of 8 members, with the Chairperson and co-Chairperson leading meetings called by them or a majority of members. SEC. 5. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Chairperson and co-Chairperson, with the approval of the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Director's pay shall not exceed Level V of the Executive Schedule. Additional staff may be appointed by the Director with approval. The Director and staff shall be appointed under title 5, United States Code, and paid according to General Schedule pay rates. The Commission may request personnel from Federal agencies to assist in its duties on a reimbursable basis. The Commission has the power to request personnel from Federal agencies for assistance on a reimbursable basis. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, request official data from government agencies, and use the United States mails. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Administrator of General Services can provide administrative support services upon request. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services to the Commission on a reimbursable basis for carrying out its responsibilities under this Act. The Commission will submit a report to the President, Congress, and the Secretary of Health and Human Services within 2 years of all original members being appointed. The report will detail findings, conclusions, and recommendations for foster care system reform. The Commission will terminate upon transmitting the report.
